regretList.regret: I regret leaving a job I love because I felt like I deserved more.

Alcohol unlocked something in my introverted nature early in my 20s, allowing me to be more outgoing, leading me to believe that my experiences and self were bound to the substance forever. In actuality, I reached a crucial fulcrum in life and drinking contributed to a malaise and two years of inactivity when I could of moved on to the adventure I knew in my heart was waiting for me (joining a community called L'Arche, which led to meeting my wife, finding a new home in midwestern city I love, and finding a vocation in social work that brings me fulfillment in relationship that I couldn't find while I was drinking).

I regret that after I divorced, I chose another partner who had a temper and turned out to be horrible to my children. I regret that I stayed with him for so long thinking that I could "mediate" every conflict and keep everyone happy. I wish I had moved out of my my home town when I was younger.

I wish I would have recognized that I was an alcoholic well before I ruined relationships...friendships, romantic relationships, family, business. In the 8th grade I robbed and trashed the home of a good friend with two other classmates. I don’t know how I came to do it. It wasn’t premeditated. Our friend wasn’t home and we just went inside and things got out of hand. The fall out was severe. Criminal action, shame, being bullied, loss of friendships, disappointment, fear. My self esteem completely evaporated. Thirty years later I think about it all the time. I daydream of going back in time to the day before. I think so many things about who I am would be different. But I also don’t know if that’s true. Maybe I never would have left home if I hadn’t felt like an outcast. I have gone on to be a good friend, neighbor, citizen. Nothing about how I acted that night relates to who went in to be in the years that followed or who I am today but it still crushes me and I can’t forgive myself. Or don’t know how.
Not divorcing my husband ten years ago

I sincerely regret the amount of time and energy I have spent trying to be likable, or to fit in. I spent so much time worrying about fitting in that I ended up becoming who others wanted, stayed in bad relationships way too long, and allowed people to stay in my life that didn't care about me. More than anything, my need to not make noise meant I didn't admit or tell anyone about the several rapes I experienced as a young adult by a family member, which resulted in several mental health breakdowns later in life. If I could talk to my 15-year-old self, I would tell her that she is EXACTLY who she is meant to be, that the people in life that are worth keeping are those that will see her value, and she must be her own advocate.
I regret staying in a relationship that wasn't fulfilling for too long./
I regret lashing out on people who hurt me. It was wrong some of the things they did. but I feel like I hurt people worse because of my anger and my inability to handle it.

When I was in college some friends introduced me to a friend of theirs who was going to school in another state. I started up an email relationship with her. At the end of one semester, she was going to drive back home halfway across the country and wanted a driving buddy. It was inconveniently timed for me because I still had tests, so I didn't offer to fly out and join her. I wish I would have figured out a way to make it happen. Who knows what would have been different if I had.

I lived about 1 mile down the street from the boyfriend who broke my heart in college after the heart had been broken. I went back to college for my senior year after a junior year abroad. He moved to the city near the campus. I had so many questions and was so hurt and I looked for him everywhere. I wish I had had the courage to call him and go for a walk or dinner and ask him why he'd ended our relationship. We were very serious and then it ended while I was studying abroad and he had moved away for a job after college. I've never really gotten over that heartbreak. And I still kick myself for not being more mature and confident in having that conversation. One evening I did run into him at a bar but there was no meaningful conversation or resolution. I just acted like I didn't care, then spent some time with him, and he broke my heart again. Terribly painful and I still didn't insist on more of an explanation. Young and proud. I did learn from it though.
I regret drinking alcohol so much and so often over the last 10 years.

I regret being a part of a high control aberrational Christian church group for over two decades. Though there was much good that happened during that time like meeting my husband, the demanding group took most of my time, energy and resources which I could have spent otherwise. I also regret the indoctrination that I succumbed to which was exploitative and which led me to suppressing my own voice, desire and needs in many situations. Leaving also was very traumatic for our family.
